metadata.titleEn: The SRTM digital elevation dataset of the Tibetan Plateau (2000)
metadata.description:
The SRTM (Shuttle Radar Topography Mission) data were obtained from the Endeavour space shuttle jointly launched by NASA and NIMA in February 2000. The SRTM system on the Endeavour had been collecting data for 222 hours and 23 minutes. It covered more than 80% of the global land surface from 60° north latitude to 56° south Latitude, including the whole territory of China. The radar image data acquired by the program have been processed for more than two years to form a digital terrain elevation model.
The raw data of this data set were downloaded from the SRTM data distribution website (http://srtm.csi.cgiar.org). For the convenience of using the data, based on the framing of STRM data, we use Erdas software to splice and prepare the STMR mosaic of the Tibetan Plateau.
The accuracy is 30 meters, and the data are in geoTIFF format.
The raw data of this data set was downloaded from the SRTM data distribution website (http://srtm.csi.cgiar.org).
The SRTM data provides a file for each latitude and longitude square. There are two kinds of longitude files, which are 1 arc-second and 3 arc-second, denoted SRTM1 and SRTM3, or 30-m and 90-m data. This data set comprises SRTM3 data with a resolution of 90 m, and the version is SRTM V4.1 (GeoTIFF format).

background: The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission produced the most complete, highest-resolution digital elevation model of the Earth. The project was a joint endeavor of NASA, the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency, and the German and Italian Space Agencies and flew in February 2000. At the foundation of modern geosciences, quite literally, is knowledge of the shape of the Earth’s surface. Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality: some with astounding accuracy, some far less adequate. It has proven exceedingly difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution by conventional means. The emergence, in the 1990s, of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry placed the possibility of efficiently and affordably creating a global digital elevation model within the grasp of spacefaring nations. Interferometric SAR, or InSAR, makes use of phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio (typically 0.0002) to measure topography.
research objective: The SRTM objective was to acquire a digital elevation model of all land between about 60° north latitude and 56° south latitude, about 80% of Earth’s land surface. The operational goal of C radar was to generate contiguous mapping coverage as called for by the mission objectives. X radar was included as an experimental demonstration. As it did not employ ScanSAR, the X band radar had a slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) than the C band system. The key to successful acquisition of a data set suitable for automated production is to remove the variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations and to measure the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects accurately at all times during data acquisition.
challenges: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality: some with astounding accuracy, some far less adequate. Furthermore, the global coverage has been uneven. It has proven exceedingly difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution by conventional means. Optical stereo mapping systems suffer from poor control and matching difficulties in areas of low contrast and from persistent cloud cover in many important areas of the world.
methods: Following the launch, the first 12 hours of flight were taken up by on-orbit checkout (OOCO), during which the payload bay doors were opened, the SRTM system was activated and checked, and the orbiter was maneuvered to the mapping attitude. Mapping continued for 149 orbits (222.4 hours). Data were acquired at the rate of 180 megabits per second (Mbps) (C radar) and at 90 Mbps (X radar). Selected snapshots of data necessary for near-real-time performance assessment were down linked via the shuttle Ku band and NASA’s tracking and data relay system (TDRS) link to JPL in Pasadena and to the Payload Operations Control Center (POCC) in Houston.
dataset: A total of 765 data takes were executed. Of these, 399 were C radar only, 1 was X radar only, and 365 were simultaneous C and X radar. The volume of data produced by SRTM, 12.3 Tb (8.6 Tb by C radar, 3.7 Tb by X radar), compares to the capacity of the Library of Congress.

Verification.Question: Is it true that traditional optical stereo mapping systems face challenges in areas with low contrast and high cloud cover?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the primary method for collecting digital elevation data through synthetic aperture radar interferometry, optical stereo mapping, or another technique?
Which challenge is more significant in creating a global digital elevation model: uneven global coverage or matching difficulties in areas of low contrast?

Concept Completion.Question: What is the purpose of the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) in data collection?
Where does the data collection coverage of the SRTM extend globally?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to create a global digital elevation model efficiently and affordably?
Example.Answer: The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission utilized synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry, which uses phase-difference measurements from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio, to efficiently and affordably create a global digital elevation model.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when producing a global digital elevation model using conventional topographic mapping technologies?
Example.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies often produce maps of uneven quality and face significant challenges in achieving consistent scale and resolution globally. Optical stereo mapping systems, for instance, struggle with poor control and matching in areas with low contrast and persistent cloud cover.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset generated from a radar mapping mission that aimed to cover a significant portion of Earth's land surface?
Example.Answer: The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) acquired a dataset covering about 80% of Earth's land surface between 60° north latitude and 56° south latitude, producing 12.3 terabytes of data using both C radar and X radar systems.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of topographic data collected using synthetic aperture radar interferometry (InSAR)?
Feature Specification.Answer: phase-difference measurements, small base to height ratio, global digital elevation model, consistent scale and resolution, covers 80% of Earth's land surface between 60° north and 56° south latitude

Feature Specification.Question: What specific challenges are associated with the collection of global digital elevation data?
Feature Specification.Answer: uneven quality, inconsistent global coverage, expense of conventional mapping methods, poor control, matching difficulties in low-contrast areas, persistent cloud cover

Quantification.Question: How many hours were dedicated to data collection during the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission?
What percentage of Earth's land surface was covered by the digital elevation model acquired during the mission?
What was the data acquisition rate for the C radar system on the SRTM mission?

Definition.Question: What is synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry, and how is it utilized in topographic data collection?
Definition.Answer: Synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry, or InSAR, is a technique that uses phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio (typically 0.0002) to measure topography. It allows for the efficient and affordable creation of a global digital elevation model by capturing high-resolution data from space.

Definition.Question: What are the primary challenges associated with conventional topographic mapping technologies, and how does radar interferometry address these challenges?
Definition.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality, with some maps being exceedingly accurate and others less adequate. The global coverage has also been inconsistent. Optical stereo mapping systems, in particular, suffer from poor control and matching difficulties in areas of low contrast and persistent cloud cover. Radar interferometry, such as that used in the SRTM mission, overcomes these challenges by providing consistent and high-resolution data unaffected by cloud cover and lighting conditions.

Definition.Question: What constitutes a digital elevation model, and what was the objective of creating one for the SRTM mission?
Definition.Answer: A digital elevation model (DEM) is a representation of Earth's surface topography. The objective of creating a DEM for the SRTM mission was to acquire high-resolution elevation data for all land between about 60° north latitude and 56° south latitude, covering approximately 80% of Earth's land surface. This endeavor aimed to produce a consistent and comprehensive global map set, which was challenging and expensive to achieve with conventional mapping technologies.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry compare to conventional topographic mapping technologies in terms of global coverage and resolution?
Comparison.Answer: Synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry, as utilized in the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM), offers more consistent global coverage and resolution compared to conventional topographic mapping technologies. Conventional methods often result in maps of uneven quality, with some regions having high accuracy and others being less adequate. SAR interferometry efficiently produces a global digital elevation model, overcoming the challenges and expenses associated with traditional methods.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of producing a digital elevation model using optical stereo mapping systems differ from those faced by synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry?
Comparison.Answer: Optical stereo mapping systems face challenges such as poor control and matching difficulties in areas of low contrast and issues with persistent cloud cover, which hinder mapping in many important regions. In contrast, synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry, used in the SRTM, effectively mitigates these challenges by using phase-difference measurements to capture topography, enabling more reliable data collection regardless of optical conditions.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences and similarities in data volume and processing between C radar and X radar used in the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission?
Comparison.Answer: The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission produced a total data volume of 12.3 Tb, with 8.6 Tb from C radar and 3.7 Tb from X radar. The C radar was used in more data takes (399 C radar only and 365 simultaneous with X radar) compared to the X radar (1 X radar only). The X radar had a slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio due to its experimental nature and lack of ScanSAR use, compared to the C radar.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of the data acquisition rates of C radar and X radar on the overall quality and resolution of the digital elevation models generated?
Interpretation.Answer: The data acquisition rates of 180 Mbps for C radar and 90 Mbps for X radar imply that the C radar was designed to generate contiguous mapping coverage as per mission objectives, while the X radar, with a slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio, served as an experimental demonstration. These differences in data rates and radar characteristics affect the quality and resolution of the resulting digital elevation models, with X radar potentially providing finer details.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the data processing techniques employed post-acquisition enhance the reliability of digital elevation models derived from radar data?
Interpretation.Answer: Post-acquisition data processing techniques, such as accurate measurement of the interferometer baseline and removal of variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations, are crucial for enhancing the reliability of digital elevation models. These techniques ensure systematic effects are accurately accounted for, contributing to a dataset that is suitable for automated production and consistent in quality.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of producing a global digital elevation model with consistent scale and resolution?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges of producing a global digital elevation model with consistent scale and resolution stem from conventional topographic mapping technologies, which have resulted in maps of uneven quality, with some having high accuracy and others less adequate. Additionally, global coverage has been uneven and optical stereo mapping systems face difficulties with control and matching in areas of low contrast and persistent cloud cover.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why was the emergence of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry significant for global digital elevation model creation?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The emergence of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry was significant because it allowed for the efficient and affordable creation of a global digital elevation model. This technology uses phase-difference measurements from two radar images with a very small base to height ratio, making it possible to measure topography accurately and overcome the limitations of conventional mapping systems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What were the reasons for including both C band and X band radar systems in the SRTM mission?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The inclusion of both C band and X band radar systems in the SRTM mission was based on the objective to acquire a comprehensive digital elevation model. The C radar aimed to generate contiguous mapping coverage, while the X band radar, included as an experimental demonstration, offered a slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio, enhancing the data quality and coverage achieved by the mission.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact on digital elevation model consistency when using interferometric SAR data versus conventional topographic mapping methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using interferometric SAR data allows for a more consistent global digital elevation model as it can efficiently and affordably create maps at a consistent scale and resolution, overcoming the uneven quality and high cost associated with conventional methods.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the inclusion of X radar as an experimental demonstration affect the overall data quality and resolution in a dataset?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The inclusion of X radar, despite not employing ScanSAR, results in a slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) than the C band system, which enhances the overall data quality and resolution of the dataset.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential challenges encountered during data acquisition for creating a digital elevation model with high-resolution interferometric SAR data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Challenges include variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations, as well as the need for accurate measurement of the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects at all times during data acquisition to ensure the production of a suitable dataset.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective behind utilizing synthetic aperture radar interferometry for global digital elevation model creation?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to efficiently and affordably create a global digital elevation model that covers all land between about 60° north latitude and 56° south latitude, which accounts for about 80% of the Earth’s land surface.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why was it necessary to employ both C and X radar systems during the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The use of C and X radar systems was crucial because C radar aimed to generate contiguous mapping coverage, while the X radar, although experimental, offered a slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio, thus enhancing the quality and scope of data acquisition.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of overcoming the challenges posed by conventional topographic mapping technologies in creating a digital elevation model?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcomes include achieving a consistent scale and resolution across the global elevation model, overcoming the uneven quality of previous mapping technologies, and providing reliable data even in areas with persistent cloud cover or low contrast, which traditional optical methods struggled to map effectively.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific steps involved in using synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry for global digital elevation model (DEM) creation?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry, or InSAR, involves using phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a small base to height ratio (typically 0.0002) to measure topography. The process includes removing variability and decorrelation from pass-to-pass observations and ensuring accurate measurements of the interferometer baseline and systematic effects during data acquisition.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How does the mapping process ensure the removal of variability and decorrelation in data acquisition for a digital elevation model?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The mapping process ensures the removal of variability and decorrelation by focusing on accurate measurement of the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects throughout the data acquisition phase. This careful management allows for consistent and reliable data suitable for automated production of digital elevation models.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are taken to manage data volume during the acquisition of radar data for a digital elevation model?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: During the acquisition of radar data, the data were acquired at rates of 180 megabits per second (Mbps) for C radar and 90 Mbps for X radar, resulting in a total data volume of 12.3 Tb, with 8.6 Tb by C radar and 3.7 Tb by X radar. Selected snapshots were downlinked via the shuttle Ku band and NASA’s tracking and data relay system (TDRS) link to the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) in Pasadena and to the Payload Operations Control Center (POCC) in Houston for near-real-time performance assessment.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enabled the efficient and affordable creation of a global digital elevation model using synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry?
Enablement.Answer: The emergence of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry in the 1990s made it possible to efficiently and affordably create a global digital elevation model. Interferometric SAR, or InSAR, uses phase-difference measurements from two radar images with a very small base to height ratio to measure topography.

Enablement.Question: What challenges did conventional topographic mapping technologies face that were overcome by the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission's approach?
Enablement.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies faced challenges such as producing maps of uneven quality and inconsistent global coverage. They also struggled with control and matching difficulties in areas of low contrast and persistent cloud cover. The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission overcame these challenges through the use of interferometric SAR, which allowed for consistent scale and resolution in mapping.

Expectation.Question: Why might the use of conventional topographic mapping technologies lead to inconsistent global digital elevation models?
Expectation.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality due to various factors, such as differing levels of accuracy and challenges with global coverage. These methods struggle with consistent scale and resolution, are costly, and suffer from issues like poor control in low-contrast areas and cloud cover.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges in using SAR interferometry for creating a global digital elevation model?
Expectation.Answer: SAR interferometry, while promising, faces challenges such as the need to remove variability and decorrelation from pass-to-pass observations and accurately measuring the interferometer baseline. These are critical for ensuring the automated production of a consistent dataset.

Judgmental.Question: What are the challenges faced in ensuring consistent scale and resolution across a global digital elevation model using radar technology?
Judgmental.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality, with some areas having astounding accuracy while others are less adequate. The global coverage has been uneven, making it difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model with consistent scale and resolution using traditional methods. Additionally, optical stereo mapping systems face issues such as poor control, matching difficulties in areas of low contrast, and persistent cloud cover in important areas.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you find synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry in overcoming the limitations of traditional topographic mapping techniques?
Judgmental.Answer: Synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry, or InSAR, emerged in the 1990s and offered a more efficient and affordable method to create a global digital elevation model. InSAR uses phase-difference measurements from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio to measure topography, which overcomes some limitations of conventional mapping techniques, such as inconsistent quality and challenging conditions for optical systems.

Judgmental.Question: What potential improvements could be made to data acquisition processes to enhance the quality and reliability of datasets derived from spaceborne radar missions?
Judgmental.Answer: The key to successful data acquisition for automated production is to remove variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations and to accurately measure the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects throughout data acquisition. Improvements could involve refining these processes to ensure more consistent and reliable datasets.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the use of synthetic aperture radar interferometry can efficiently create a global digital elevation model.
Assertion.Answer: Synthetic aperture radar interferometry uses phase-difference measurements from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio to measure topography, enabling efficient and affordable creation of a global digital elevation model.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges that conventional topographic mapping technologies face in producing a consistent global map set.
Assertion.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies produce maps of uneven quality and global coverage, making it difficult and expensive to create a consistent scale and resolution map set. Optical stereo mapping systems particularly struggle with control and matching in low contrast areas and persistent cloud cover.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data from the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission was processed into a digital elevation model after acquisition.
Assertion.Answer: The data acquired by the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission underwent processing over two years to create a digital elevation model, using snapshots and downlinked data for performance assessments and systematic effect measurements to ensure consistency and accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the methodologies used to ensure consistent scale and resolution in digital elevation models derived from satellite radar data.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methodologies include the use of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry, which employs phase-difference measurements from two radar images with a small base to height ratio to measure topography. Ensuring consistent scale and resolution involves accurately measuring the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects during data acquisition.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced when producing a global digital elevation model using conventional topographic mapping technologies.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include producing maps of uneven quality, with some maps having high accuracy and others being inadequate. Conventional mapping methods struggle with global coverage and are often costly. Optical stereo mapping systems face poor control and matching issues in low contrast areas and persistent cloud cover in significant regions.
